---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [812755553c](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14375/commits/812755553cd9a0ef3bbdf2f6754f0fa0b0e66ca8)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.LocalRing.Module`|1467|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ LocalRing.split_injective_iff_lTensor_residueField_injective`
`+ TensorProduct.mk_surjective`
`+ free_of_flat_of_localRing`
`+ free_of_lTensor_residueField_injective`
`+ free_of_maximalIdeal_rTensor_injective`
`+ lTensor_injective_of_exact_of_exact_of_rTensor_injective`
`+ map_mkQ_eq`
`+ map_mkQ_eq_top`
`+ map_tensorProduct_mk_eq_top`
`+ span_eq_top_of_tmul_eq_basis`
`+ subsingleton_tensorProduct`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by faenuccio.
Thanks for the swift review!
Canceled.
bors d+

:v: erdOne can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9806021875/job/27076900377)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9806021875/job/27076899982)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
I have read the first 200 lines of  `Module.lean` up to the declaration `Module.free_of_lTensor_residueField_injective`
Thanks so much for all the work!

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
Any specific reason for putting `R` as a localized variable and leaving `S` inside the statement? What about having `variable (R S) in` before the theorem?
`variable (R) in` makes the variable explicit, but there is not a global `variable {S}` living around.
I agree, but `variable (R S)` has the same effect... Not very important, at any rate.

```suggestion
This file gathers various results about finite modules over a local ring `(R, 𝔪, k)`.
```

```suggestion
  `N` finite and `M` finite free, then injectivity of `k ⊗ N → k ⊗ M` implies that `P` is free.
```

```suggestion
  Given an `R`-linear map `l : M → N` with `M` finite and `N` finite free,
```

```suggestion
  `l` is a split injection if and only if `k ⊗ l` is a (split) injection.
```
Do you want to add the `[LocalRing R]` variable to the above line where you introduce `R` and `S`?
Why do you prefer to prepend `LocalRing` here (and `Module` later) rather than opening the relevant namespaces?

If you put `LocalRing.map_mkQ_eq_top` *after* `LocalRing.map_mkQ_eq`, its proof simply becomes
```
  convert LocalRing.map_mkQ_eq (N₁ := N) (N₂ := ⊤) le_top Module.Finite.out
  simp only [Submodule.map_top, Submodule.range_mkQ]
  ```
Isn't there a notation for this tensor product?
`TensorProduct.mk R k M 1 x` has the notation `1 ⊗ₜ x`, but here it is referring to the linear map.

```suggestion
    ← map_mk_eq_top (M := M), Submodule.map_bot]
```
Do you want to add some reference to the "tensor product" in the name of the theorem?
I renamed it to `LocalRing.map_tensorProduct_mk_eq_top`
Some reference to the tensor product in the name?
I think `tmul` means tensor product-multiplication in mathlib?
Why not moving these variables outside? I do not have a strong preference, I try to understand if there is a rationale here.
It pollutes the info view of other proofs.
Good point!
Why not leaving `f₁, f₂, g₁, g₂` implicit? I tried in the application below and it works.

```suggestion
Given `M₁ → M₂ → M₃ → 0` and `N₁ → N₂ → N₃ → 0`,
if `M₁ ⊗ N₃ → M₂ ⊗ N₃` and `M₂ ⊗ N₁ → M₂ ⊗ N₂` are both injective,
```

```suggestion
    simp only [← hx, ← LinearMap.comp_apply, ← LinearMap.comp_apply, LinearMap.rTensor_comp_lTensor,
      LinearMap.lTensor_comp_rTensor]
```

```suggestion
    apply hginj
    simp only [← hy, ← LinearMap.comp_apply, ← LinearMap.comp_apply, LinearMap.lTensor_comp_rTensor,
      LinearMap.rTensor_comp_lTensor]
```
Since the proof is a bit long, can you add some comments along it to help readers?
Is this comment left here intentionally?
Both here and three lines above, what is the interest of `inst`? I commented it and nothing changed.
It used to timeout without them. Not sure what changed.

```suggestion
  -- We claim that `i` is actually a bijection, hence an isomorphism exhibing `M` as the free module `Rᴵ`.
```

```suggestion
`M` finite and `N` finite free, then injectivity of `k ⊗ M → k ⊗ N` implies that `P` is free.
```

```suggestion
with `M` finite and `N` finite free,
`l` is a split injection if and only if `k ⊗ l` is a (split) injection.
```
Can you rather refer to the name of the declaration instead of "lemma above"?

It is directly on the next line though.
I've changed the wording a bit but I'll include the lemma name if you still think it's better to do so.

I think so, because in the future people might move things around and it won't be "above" anymore (and given the lack of attention that is normally taken at the doc, it is likely they would forget to update).

To clarify, the current wording is 
```
    -- By the a previously proved lemma, `k ⊗ l` injective => `N ⧸ l(M)` free.
    have := Module.free_of_lTensor_residueField_injective l (LinearMap.range l).mkQ
```
And you suggest
```
    -- By `Module.free_of_lTensor_residueField_injective`, `k ⊗ l` injective => `N ⧸ l(M)` free.
    have := Module.free_of_lTensor_residueField_injective l (LinearMap.range l).mkQ
```
Yes, thanks!

```suggestion
    -- Hence `l(M)` is projective because `0 → l(M) → N → N ⧸ l(M) → 0` splits.
```

```suggestion
      exact Module.Projective.of_split _ _ (this.mp
          <| Module.projective_lifting_property _ _ <| Submodule.mkQ_surjective _).2
```
I don't know why but this gives a `(kernel) invalid projection ⋯.1` error for me.

Can you explain this point a bit more? The next declaration `H` is just an injectivity, while here (and later on) the splitting plays a role. Perhaps you could introduce `l'` in the previous comment as the map `l(M) -> M` and here say that this injective map stays injective after `k ⊗ -`.
The logic here is `0 → ker l → M → l(M) → 0` splits => `k ⊗ ker l → k ⊗ M → k ⊗ l(M) → 0` splits => `k ⊗ ker l → k ⊗ M` injective. And we only need injectivity later on.
Oh, I see. Then I would rather say in this comment that since the first sequence splits, tensoring with `k` preserves injectivity of the first arrow in the second sequence. (which is `H`).
Oddly enough, one cannot simply insert the RHS of the previous line in this `rw`, while passing through a `this`, works. Do you know why?
This is a known quirk of the `tfae` implementation in mathlib.
I think this is true for any finite module, maybe we can add a TODO (the proof is much harder IIRC).
We're actually not that far away. We already have the equational criterion of flatness and finite flat = free is a (relatively) easy application of that. Anyways I added a TODO.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(RingTheory/LocalRing/Module): Finitely presented flat modules over local rings are free.
